peak tells you about the width of the peak and the direction
- if below .5 peak goes down
-- the closer to 0 the narrower the downward peak
- if above .5 peak goes up
-- the closer to 1 the narrower the upwards peak
-- though if it is close to .5 there really isn't any peaks: could by jagged or a smooth increase then decrease sort of like a normal curve or vice versa
- between .25 and .75 seems to be inconclusive


(defn peak [col] (double (/ (count (filter #(< % (mean col)) col)) (count col))))

(defn sign-changes [col] (double (/ (count (filter #(not= (first %) (second %)) (partition 2 1 (map #(if (< % (mean col)) 1 0) col)))) (dec (count col)))))

popsicle.core=> (for [col [v v2 v3 v3-2 v4 v5 v6 v7 v8 v8-2]] (peak col))
(0.75 0.5 0.25 0.25 0.3181818181818182 0.4666666666666667 0.46875 0.495 0.2857142857142857 0.5)
popsicle.core=> (for [col [v v2 v3 v3-2 v4 v5 v6 v7 v8 v8-2]] (sign-changes col))
(0.4285714285714286 1.0 0.1818181818181818 0.1818181818181818 0.1904761904761905 0.3793103448275862 0.1290322580645161 0.4994994994994995 0.5384615384615385 1.0)
popsicle.core=> (doseq [col [v v2 v3 v3-2 v4 v5 v6 v7 v8 v8-2]] (vv col))
nil
popsicle.core=> (for [col [v v2 v3 v3-2 v4 v5 v6 v7 v8 v8-2]] col)
